translated: The DhÄraá¹‡Ä« SÅ«tra of the Great VidyÄ of AparÄjitÄ
Tripiá¹­aka Master from the Western Regions, Chao-san-ta-fu
Shi-hong-lu-shao-qing, the Dharma-transmitting Great Master, subjectğŸ”½I take refuge and pay homage to the Perfectly Enlightened One,
As well as the Dharma and the assembly of sages and saints.ğŸ”½The Bodhisattvas expound this vidyÄ,
Which is said to destroy obstacles.
The evil dharmas of all the VetÄá¸a, Kaá¹­apÅ«tanÄ, and PÅ«tana spirits,
And the evil methods created by the hosts of Yaká¹£as and RÄká¹£asas,
This vidyÄ can destroy them and always cause correct practice.
If there are sentient beings who sincerely and single-mindedly uphold this vidyÄ mantra,ğŸ”½Either by writing it on silk or cloth,
Or by writing it on birch bark or paper,
In all those places, the evil ghosts and spirits will give rise to definitive kindness.
Eliminating calamities and hindrances, accomplishing the most excellent matters.
If one wears it on one's neck and enters into a military battle,
While others are killing each other, it can protect and uphold.
The mind is free from confusion and fear, not harming a single hair.
If one wears it on one's arm, one will quickly gain victory.
As the Buddha said:
If there are men and women who uphold this mantra,
all their desired matters will be accomplished.
If they are bound by royal law,
if they encounter the danger of lions, tigers, and wolves while traveling in the wilderness,
if they encounter thieves following them on the road,
the power of this great mantra can protect them,
freeing them from all fears and enabling them to attain peace and happiness.
If a woman wears it on her head and upholds it,
she will always be loved and respected by her family and constantly obtain wealth and treasures.
If she is pregnant and has difficulty giving birth, she will quickly attain peace and safety.
The great mantra spoken by the Bodhisattva,
protecting day and night, is always so.
If there is a wise person who single-mindedly upholds it,
whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down,
demons and other difficulties will not be able to harm them.
Even if drunk or sleeping, they will have no bad dreams.
That invincible mantra,
if held, recited, and chanted,
All the disputes among the kings, villagers, and multitudes will be completely eliminated.
All obstacles and difficulties will be completely dispelled.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Ajitasena said to the demons,
I will now explain.
You, the multitude of BhÅ«tas, listen to what I say.
The Bodhisattva sees the evil demon armies
With various forms and colors standing before him.
He speaks to those demon armies, saying,
For koá¹­is of kalpas, I have sought enlightenment.
I have given up my own life, wife, children, and wealth.
I have done what is difficult to do and practiced great diligence.
For the benefit and peace of all beings,
I have fulfilled my vows and dwell at the Bodhi tree.
I have realized the true Dharma and cherish it deeply.
At that time, the demon king leads his evil troops to come and create obstacles.
By the power of the bright mantra, they are subdued.
I rejoice in the past demons being subdued by my thoughts.
Past enemies are destroyed by themselves.
I will now explain the destruction of the demon armies.
The great bright mantra says:
Tadyatha hulu hulu chan-na li-ma-deng-ye svaha When the Bodhisattva Ajitasena spoke this mantra,
He transformed his body into the form of a celestial maiden,
Stood in front of Mara, and gave rise to a compassionate mind.ğŸ”½With palms joined, he said from above Mara's head, The bodhisattva's pure mind,
As I speak of the supreme truth,
With great wisdom and great light, forever severing the darkness of ignorance.
In the past, seeking enlightenment, Mara's army has now been subdued.
Having subdued Mara's hordes, he attains great fearlessness,
Forever leaving the world, he will certainly achieve perfect enlightenment.
For the sake of the celestial and human teachers, he quickly delivers all beings.
You all see this, giving rise to great joy in your hearts.
Mara, the lord of the demons, and his retinue, cannot set foot on the banks of the NairaÃ±janÄ River.
Now, by the power of the bright mantra, he shatters the veil of afflictions.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Ajitasena,
With a subtle and wonderful Brahma voice, pervading the ten directions.
Then he explained the text, saying:
